title: All about Stool Samples: How to Collect and When to Refrigerate

steps.title: Wash your hands
steps.content: Wash your hands before and after collecting your sample. This is pretty self-explanatory—since you’re getting pretty hands-on with your poo, it’s important to keep your hands as clean as possible throughout the process. [1] X Research source Make sure to wash your hands with soap and water for at least 20 seconds before and after you finish with your sample. [2] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source To be extra sanitary, slip on a pair of disposable gloves before you get started. [3] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source

steps.title: Pick up a stool collection kit from your doctor.
steps.content: Pick up a stool collection kit from your doctor. If your doctor specifically requested a stool test, they likely gave you a collection kit for your sample, which includes a pre-labeled plastic container with a screw-on cap. [4] X Research source If you weren’t given a kit yet, ask your doctor if they can get you one (or where you can pick one up).

steps.title: Write your name, date of birth, and the current date on the container.
steps.content: Write your name, date of birth, and the current date on the container. Use a marker or pen to fill out the label that came with your container, if there is one. Otherwise, use a marker to write the information directly on the container. [5] X Trustworthy Source State of Massachusetts Official website for the State of Massachusetts Go to source This will help the lab keep track of your specimen while they’re testing and analyzing it. Your test kit might have also come with a separate form—be sure to fill this out with your name, birthdate, address, and any other requested info.

steps.title: Pee before you collect the stool sample.
steps.content: Pee before you collect the stool sample. Make sure that your bladder is completely empty before you poop—this will prevent your specimen from getting contaminated. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Drape plastic wrap over the toilet bowl
steps.content: Drape plastic wrap over the toilet bowl to catch the stool. Lift up the toilet seat and wrap a large sheet of plastic wrap overtop. Then, press into the very center of the wrap to make an indent that’ll collect your poop. [7] X Trustworthy Source State of Massachusetts Official website for the State of Massachusetts Go to source If your plastic wrap doesn’t seem super secure, hold it in place with some tape. Some test kits might come with a “ toilet hat ” that goes directly over your toilet bowl and is held in place with the toilet seat. True to its name, it resembles an upside-down hat. [8] X Research source Some kits may come with paper that you can drape over your toilet bowl. [9] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source This step prevents toilet water from contaminating your sample.

steps.title: Poop directly into the plastic wrap.
steps.content: Poop directly into the plastic wrap. Sit on the toilet and pass a bowel movement like you normally would. Thanks to the indent you made earlier, the stool will collect in the middle of the plastic wrap. [10] X Trustworthy Source State of Massachusetts Official website for the State of Massachusetts Go to source

steps.title: Collect the stool sample with a disposable spoon or wooden stick.
steps.content: Collect the stool sample with a disposable spoon or wooden stick. Using the stick or spoon, transfer the required amount of stool into the plastic container. [11] X Research source Check your test kit instructions to see how much stool you need to collect. Many tests require a coin-sized amount (like a US quarter) for the sample. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Compile the items you used to collect your stool and toss them out.
steps.content: Compile the items you used to collect your stool and toss them out. Place the spoon or wooden stick in the plastic bag first. Then, retrieve the plastic wrap or paper from the toilet and put it in the bag. Seal the plastic bag and throw it out. [13] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source

steps.title: Slip the stool sample container into a sealable plastic bag.
steps.content: Slip the stool sample container into a sealable plastic bag. Double-check that the specimen container is closed before sliding and sealing it into the plastic bag. Check your test kit instructions and see if the sample needs to be placed in a brown paper bag or covered in foil instead (to keep it out of the light).

steps.title: Refrigerate the sample for up to 1 day if you can’t deliver it within 30 minutes.
steps.content: Refrigerate the sample for up to 1 day if you can’t deliver it within 30 minutes. Stool samples are very time sensitive—the sooner they make it to the laboratory, the better. If you can’t head over to the doctor’s office or laboratory right away, stash the specimen in your fridge so it won’t expire. [14] X Trustworthy Source State of Oregon Official website for the State of Oregon Go to source The sample will stay fresh for up to an extra day. Make sure that your fridge is set to 4 °C (39 °F) when you store the sample.

steps.title: Deliver the stool sample to a laboratory as soon as you can.
steps.content: Deliver the stool sample to a laboratory as soon as you can. Even when refrigerated, stool samples don’t last very long. Deliver the sample to your doctor, the laboratory, or another collection center within 24 hours (which is the max length of time you can refrigerate a sample). If you’re collecting your stool sample in the summer (or you live in a warm area), it might help to transport the specimen in a cooler during your drive to the laboratory or doctor’s office.

steps.title: Collect the sample using your test kit.
steps.content: Collect the sample using your test kit. Start by draping a sheet of stool collection paper over the toilet water—many testing kits come with this. Then, poop on top of the collection paper, relieving yourself as you normally would. [15] X Research source To prevent any pee from compromising your specimen, relieve yourself before you produce and collect any stool. Mail-in stool samples are typically collected as part of a Fecal Immunochemical Test (FIT), which scans for blood in your stool (which is a potential sign of colon cancer). [16] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source

steps.title: Scrape up a stool sample and apply it to your test card.
steps.content: Scrape up a stool sample and apply it to your test card. Step away from the toilet and grab the disposable brush (also called a FIT stick) that came in your test kit. Brush along the top of the stool (wherever there isn’t any toilet water contamination). Then, swipe the stool onto the designated spot on your FIT test card. [17] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source You can flush the toilet once you’ve collected the sample—the stool collection paper won’t clog your sewer or septic system. [18] X Research source

steps.title: Mail in your stool sample within 2 days of collecting it.
steps.content: Mail in your stool sample within 2 days of collecting it. While you don’t have to refrigerate your test card, you shouldn’t keep it lying around your home indefinitely. Be sure to mail your sample as soon as you can—that way, it has plenty of time to arrive at the laboratory. [19] X Research source FIT tests need to be processed within 2 weeks of collection, which is why it’s important to mail them so soon.
